smell_analysis.justification: Every numbered page that contains a diagram (pages 1-16) shows at least one model element such as a package, use case, class, table, activity action, or state; no page is an empty diagram.

The only explicit use case diagram is 'Tournaments functional subsystem' (page 2). The text extraction does not show any oval use case that is clearly unassociated with all actors, and the presence or absence of specific association lines cannot be determined unambiguously from the text alone, so no clear violation can be asserted.

Within the 'Tournaments functional subsystem' use case diagram (page 2), all use case names describe distinct activities (e.g., 'Register tournament', 'Activate tournament', 'Cancel tournament', 'Delete tournament') and there is no pair of use cases whose names clearly describe the same activity for the same actor.

The only package-style overview, 'Tournaments FSS related actors and registers' (page 1), lists different subsystem/register names (Tournaments functional subsystem, Person register, Classifier register, etc.) and does not show multiple model elements with the same primary name inside the same package.

In the transformed database diagrams (pages 12-16), repeated domain values (e.g., person_id, tournament_id, gender_code) appear only as primary keys in one table and foreign keys in others, with explicit FK connectors (e.g., FK_player_tournament_points_tournament, FK_person_gender). There is no clear case where the same data value is stored redundantly in multiple tables without a foreign key connection.

All visible use case names on the 'Tournaments functional subsystem' diagram (page 2) use a consistent verb-object form (e.g., 'Register tournament pair', 'Delete tournament court', 'View registered pairs', 'Authenticate user'), so no inconsistent naming form is present.

In the 'Tournament state diagram' (page 10), every state (Initial, Pending, Active, Completed, Cancelled, Deleted) has at least one incoming path derived from another state or the initial pseudostate via labeled transitions (e.g., creation leads to Pending, activation from Pending to Active, then completion or cancellation, and deletion from Pending). No state is clearly unreachable.

In both activity diagrams ('Register player for tournament' on page 3 and 'Create tournament' on page 4), each action node is part of a connected control flow path from the initial node (Start) through decisions and subsequent actions; there is no action that appears isolated without any incoming path.

For UML class diagrams (pages 5-9, 11) all visible associations include multiplicity labels such as 1, 0..1, or 0..*, and the transformed database diagrams (pages 12-16) use explicit FK-style connectors with implied or shown cardinalities, which the rules exempt. There is no relationship line that clearly lacks multiplicity indicators at both ends.

The 'Tournaments functional subsystem' use case diagram (page 2) contains at least 12 distinct use cases inside the system boundary (Authenticate user, Complete tournament, Register tournament pair, Activate tournament, Register tournament, Delete tournament, Modify tournament, View registered pairs, Cancel tournament, Delete tournament pair, Register tournament court, Delete tournament court). Since actors and packages are not counted, these 12 use cases exceed the threshold of 10 central elements. All other class, state, and database diagrams in the PDF show fewer than 10 classes/tables/states on a single diagram.

In the 'Tournaments register (transformed)' database diagram (page 12), the table 'tournament' has distinct foreign-key relationships to at least six different tables: person (two roles, via FK_tournament_person and FK_tournament_person_02), tournament_category (FK_tournament_tournament_category), tournament_status (FK_tournament_tournament_status), tournament_pair (FK_tournament_pair_tournament), tournament_court_link (FK_tournament_court_link_tournament), and player_tournament_points (FK_player_tournament_points_tournament). These represent six or more separate relationship lines from a single table on the same diagram, exceeding the S1.2 threshold.

Based on the available PDF rendering, the diagrams do not show any pair of related elements whose separation is explicitly more than twice the average spacing between elements; there is no clear, documented case of extreme distance between connected elements. Without explicit geometric information, no unambiguous S2.1 violation can be identified.

All visible use case names ('Authenticate user', 'Register tournament pair', 'Cancel tournament', etc., page 2) and activity actions ('Navigate to tournament list', 'Submit registration', 'Assign referee', 'Validate data', etc., pages 3-4) begin with active verbs, so the naming rule for use cases and activity actions is satisfied.

Across diagrams, class and table names (e.g., Tournament, PlayerTournamentPoints, person, tournament_pair) and attribute/column names (e.g., created_at, tournament_id, given_name, points_earned) are longer than three characters. No class, table, attribute, or use case name consisting of three or fewer characters (such as 'id' or 'usr') is visible.

In UML class diagrams such as 'Players register' (page 8) and 'Tournaments register' (page 9), the class 'PlayerTournamentPoints' is used to represent a single conceptual entity, but its name is grammatically plural due to 'Points', while other classes are singular (e.g., Player, Tournament, TournamentPair). This violates the rule that class names should not be plural.

All attributes and columns listed in class and database diagrams (e.g., created_at, date_of_birth, email, tournament_id, points_earned, court_id) begin with lowercase letters; uppercase-leading names are only used for types (e.g., DateTime, Integer) or constraint names (PK_*, FK_*), which are outside the scope of this rule.

In the transformed database diagrams, most table names are singular (e.g., tournament, player, court, person), but the table 'player_tournament_points' (pages 12-13) uses the plural word 'points' even though each row represents a single record of points for one player and tournament. This makes the table name plural and inconsistent with the singular style of other entity tables.

No class, table, or attribute name uses type-indicating prefixes like 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'strName'. The only prefixes present (PK_, FK_, pfK_, IXFK_) are attached to key and index identifiers, which are explicitly permitted by the rule and are not class, table, or attribute names themselves.
